official-title.#text:
To amend title XVIII of the Social Security Act to provide bundled payments for post-acute care
			 services under parts A and B of Medicare, and for other purposes.

committee-name.#tail: , and in addition to the Committee on

, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such
			 provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Bundling and Coordinating Post-Acute Care Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Bundling and Coordinating Post-Acute Care Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
The purposes of this Act are to—

foster the delivery of high-quality post-acute care services in the most cost-effective manner
			 possible;

preserve the ability of patients, with the guidance of their physicians, to select their preferred
			 providers of post-acute care services;

promote competition among post-acute care providers on the basis of quality, cost, accountability,
			 and customer service;

achieve long-term sustainability by ensuring operational stability through regional breadth and the
			 engagement of experienced care PAC coordinators;

advance innovation in fields including telehealth, care coordination, medication management, and
			 hospitalization avoidance; and

provide for the financial security of the Medicare program by achieving substantial program savings
			 through maximized efficiencies, cost avoidance, and outcomes improvement.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by inserting after
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Title XVIII of the Social Security Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: the following new section:

The requirements specified in this paragraph, with respect to an entity serving a PAC area, are the
			 following:

The entity has the capacity, and provides sufficient assurances of solvency, to bear financial risk
			 as a PAC coordinator under this section.
The entity has the capability to manage the care and funding for PAC services in such area.

header.#text: Capacity to manage care and funding

text.#text:
The entity has entered into PAC network agreements with one or more PAC providers in a PAC area in
			 a manner sufficient to ensure the availability of PAC services for
			 individuals residing in the area who select the entity for the furnishing
			 of PAC services.

header.#text: Limitation on selection due to network adequacy
Selection and change of selection of PAC coordinators by individual

text.#text:
Nothing in this section shall be construed as prohibiting PAC providers from offering, either
			 directly or indirectly, services that contribute to patient care, safety,
			 and readmission avoidance (such as medication management, telehealth
			 technologies, home environment services, and transportation services) that
			 are not PAC services.

header.#text: Construction relating to PAC coordinators offering non-PAC services

text.#text:
Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent a PAC network agreement from permitting a PAC
			 provider to subcontract for the furnishing of PAC services that the PAC
			 provider is otherwise obligated to provide under the agreement so long as
			 the subcontractor meets the same terms and conditions in furnishing such
			 services as would apply if the PAC provider were to provide such services.

header.#text: Construction regarding flexibility in the delivery of PAC services

text.#text: Based on the most recent data available, the

header.#text: Determination of PAC expenditures by CRG

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall rank the CRGs in order based on the aggregate amount of expenditures for PAC
			 services described in clause (i) for each CRG.

text.#text: The

header.#text: Ranking of CRGs by volume of expenditure

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall group CRGs into four groups as follows:

text.#text: The

The first group consists of the CRGs that have the highest rank under clause (ii) and that
			 collectively account for 25 percent of the aggregate amount of
			 expenditures for PAC services described in clause (i).

The second group consists of the CRGs that have the next highest rank under clause (ii) after the
			 first group in subclause (I) and that collectively account for 25 percent
			 of the aggregate amount of expenditures for PAC services described in
			 clause (i).

The third group consists of the CRGs that have the next highest rank under clause (ii) after the
			 second group in subclause (II) and that collectively account for 25
			 percent of the aggregate amount of expenditures for PAC services described
			 in clause (i).

The fourth group consists of the CRGs that are not included in the first, second, or third group
			 under this clause.
In applying this section for discharges in—

2016, only discharges that are classified within the first group under subclause (I) of clause
			 (iii) shall be included;

2017, only discharges that are classified within the first or second group under subclause (I) or
			 (II) of clause (iii) shall be included;

2018, only discharges that are classified within the first, second, or third group under subclause
			 (I), (II), or (III) of clause (iii) shall be included; and

2019 and subsequent years, discharges that are classified within any group of CRGs shall be
			 included.
